body.p: DITA provides a mechanism for profiling content (making it conditional). You can profile content elements or map elements by adding one or more of the DITA profiling attributes (product, platform, audience, rev, props, and other props). The profiling attributes may contain one or more tokens which represent conditions to be applied to the content when a publication is built.
For example, you could define a section of a topic that will be included only for a publication related to the Windows platform by adding the product profiling attribute:

section.title: Profiling content
section.p: To apply a profiling attribute to an element in a topic or a map, right click on the element and choose Edit Profiling Attributes. The Edit Profiling Attributes dialog will be displayed, allowing you to check each of the profiling tokens that apply for each attribute.
The profiling attributes and their potential values that appear in this dialog box will depend on what has been configured in your copy of . The contents of the dialog will be determined as follows:

ul.li: If your root DITA map references a DITA subject scheme map that defines values for the profiling attributes, those values will be used. In the image above, which is taken from the documentation project, values are defined for seven different product version, but none for other profiling attributes, which are therefore omitted from the dialog.
If your project defines project level configuration values for the profiling attributes, those values will be used.
If your copy of defines global level configuration values for the profiling attributes, they will be used.
Otherwise a basic default set of profiling attributes and values will be available.

section.title: Visualizing profiled content
section.p: You can visualize the effect of profiling content by using the profiling tools in the DITA Maps Manage. Click the Profiling/Conditional Text button to select which profiles to show or to apply different colors to text profiled in different ways, as shown in the image below.
